text.jahia:value:
EPFL IC DCSL

INN 237 (Bâtiment INN) - Station 14
CH-1015 Lausanne - Switzerland

Phone: +41 21 693 47 07
edouard.bugnion@epfl.ch


Edouard Bugnion joined EPFL in 2012, where his focus is on datacenter systems. His areas of interest include operating systems, datacenter infrastructure (systems and networking), and computer architecture.

Before joining EPFL, Edouard spent 18 years in the US, where he studied at Stanford and co-founded two startups: VMware and Nuova Systems (acquired by Cisco). At VMware from 1998 until 2005, he played many roles including CTO. At Nuova/Cisco from 2005 until 2011, he helped build the core engineering team and became the VP/CTO of Cisco’s Server, Access, and Virtualization Technology Group, a group that brought to market Cisco’s Unified Computing System (UCS) platform for virtualized datacenters.

Together with his colleagues, he received the ACM Software System Award for VMware 1.0 in 2009. His paper "Disco: Running Commodity Operating Systems on Scalable Multiprocessors" received a Best Paper Award at SOSP '97 and was entered into the ACM SIGOPS Hall of Fame Award in 2008. At EPFL, he received the OSDI 2014 Best Paper Award for his work on the IX dataplane operating system.

EPFL IC DCSL

BC 124 (Bâtiment BC) - Station 14
CH-1015 Lausanne - Switzerland

Phone: +41 21 693 66 69
jonas.fietz@epfl.ch

 

Jonas Fietz received his Diploma in Mathematics as well as in Computer Science from the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT). After joining the Data Center Systems Laboratory and the Networking Architecture Group NAL at EPFL in 2013, he has been working on virtual overlay networks and software defined networking for his PhD.

EPFL IC DCSL

INN 235 (Bâtiment INN) - Station 14
CH-1015 Lausanne - Switzerland

Phone: +41 21 693 40 16
marios.kogias@epfl.ch

 Marios Kogias received his M.Sc. in Electrical and Computer Engineering from the National Technical University of Athens in 2014. He is a second-year PhD student working with Edouard Bugnion @DCSL on tools and methodologies for latency measurement.

EPFL IC DCSL

INN 233 (Bâtiment INN) - Station 14
CH-1015 Lausanne - Switzerland

Phone: +41 21 693 37 61
stanko.novakovic@epfl.ch



Stanko Novakovic is a PhD student under the supervision of Edouard Bugnion and Babak Falsafi. His interests encompass many aspects of computer systems, with an emphasis on operating systems, distributed systems, and computer architecture. His ongoing research efforts focus on hardware and software systems designed for datacenter-scale applications and services, such as analytics and data serving.

Stanko received his B.S. and M.S. degrees in electrical and computer engineering from the University of Novi Sad, Serbia, in 2010 and 2011, respectively. In 2013 he interned at Microsoft Research in Cambridge, UK, and in 2014 at HP Labs in Palo Alto, USA. His research is sponsored by the Microsoft Research Swiss JRC.

EPFL IC DCSL

INN 235 (Bâtiment INN) - Station 14
CH-1015 Lausanne - Switzerland

Phone: +41 21 693 40 16
george.prekas@epfl.ch


George Prekas received his M.Sc. in Electrical and Computer Engineering from the National Technical University of Athens in 2010. As of September 2013, he joined the Data Center Systems Laboratory to pursue a PhD and also contributes to the IX project. He has been awarded a Google European Fellowship for 2015.

EPFL IC DCSL

INN 231 (Bâtiment INN) - Station 14
CH-1015 Lausanne - Switzerland

Phone: +41 21 693 31 49
mia.primorac@epfl.ch


Mia Primorac received her BSc and MSc degree in Computing from University of Zagreb in 2012 and 2014. In 2013 she completed a summer internship at Operating Systems Laboratory at EPFL. She joined the IX project in the Data Center Systems Laboratory at EPFL in September 2014 to pursue a PhD.

EPFL IC DCSL

INJ 215 (Bâtiment INJ) - Station 14
CH-1015 Lausanne - Switzerland

Phone: +41 21 693 67 08
dmitrii.ustiugov@epfl.ch

 

Dmitrii Ustiugov received his M.S. and B.S. in Applied Mathematics and Physics from Moscow institute of Physics and Technology. After spending 4 years in semiconductor and Big Data industry, Dmitrii joined EPFL as a Ph.D. student co-advised by Prof. Babak Falsafi and Prof. Edouard Bugnion. Dmitrii is interested in architecture support for datacenter systems and rack-scale computing.

EPFL IC DCSL

INN 231 (Bâtiment INN) - Station 14
CH-1015 Lausanne - Switzerland

Phone: +41 21 693 31 49
sam.whitlock@epfl.ch


Sam Whitlock began his PhD in September 2013 after receiving his B.S. from UC Berkeley in EECS. He has worked on cluster management systems (Mesos) and Software-defined Networking (SDN Troubleshooting). He now focuses on hardware acceleration for software-defined networking in the datacenter and is pursuing a PhD in the Data Center Systems Laboratory.

Courses 2016 - 2017

 

Principles of Computer Systems

This advanced graduate course focuses on key design principles underlying successful computer and communication systems, and teaches how to solve real problems using ideas, techniques, and algorithms from operating systems, networks, databases, programming... >>

System Programming Project

The objective of this project-based course is to give students extensive practice with writing, debugging, reading, understanding and improving systems programs. >>
Section of Communication Systems, 2016-2017, Bachelor semester 4, French
Section of Computer Science, 2016-2017, Bachelor semester 4, French
Section of Computer Science, 2016-2017, Spring semester, French
Minor, 2016-2017 Spring semester, French

Scale-out NUMA (soNUMA) is a high-performance rack-scale system for scale-out analytics and data serving. Each soNUMA server relies on a locally cache coherent, integrated Remote Memory Controller (RMC) to access non-local data. The RMC exposes a set of one-sided, RDMA-like operations implemented via in-memory queue-pairs. The RMC protocol is layered on top of a conventional NUMA transport.

 

Scale-out NUMA (soNUMA)

IX is an open-source project available at ix-project

Commodity operating systems fail in maintaining the high throughput and low (tail) latency when applications require millions of operations per second and just hundreds of microseconds for slowest requests. However, these requirements are not rare in today's datacenters (e.g. for key-value stores) where every individual slack off in latency effects multiple requests due to distributed fan-out computational model. Overprovisioning of resources is often the big hammer of taming the latency curve which leads to low utilization of datacenters.

IX is a specialized dataplane library operating system that solves the 4-way trade-off between high throughput, low latency, strong protection and energy efficiency. IX separates the control plane from the dataplane using hardware virtualization, therefore maintaining the strong protection offered by existing kernels. The control plane implements resource allocation policies while the dataplane provides high networking I/O performance.

The network processing is optimized for both throughput and latency of event-driven latency critical applications by processing to completion bounded batches of packets, and by minimizing coherence traffic and multi-core synchronization. The control plane dynamically manages the resources (cores and frequency) driven by different policies (e.g. energy proportionality).

Prekas, George; Belay, Adam; Primorac, Mia; Klimovic, Ana; Grossman, Samuel; Kogias, Marios; Gütermann, Bernard; Kozyrakis, Christos; Bugnion, Edouard. IX Open-source version 1.0 - Deployment and Evaluation Guide. EPFL Technical Report, 2016. Publication

G. Prekas, M. Primorac, A. Belay, C. Kozyrakis and E. Bugnion. Energy Proportionality and Workload Consolidation for Latency-Critical Applications. 2015 ACM Symposium on Cloud Computing, Kohala Coast, HI, USA, 2015. Publication

A. Belay, G. Prekas, A. Klimovic, S. Grossman and C. Kozyrakis et al. IX: A Protected Dataplane Operating System for High Throughput and Low Latency. 11th Symposium on Operating System Design and Implementation (OSDI), Broomfield, CO, USA, 2014. Publication

• IX -- a specialized operating system for datacenter applications

  • soNUMA -- rack-scale computing

  • VDP -- rack-scale software-defined networking

Microsoft Research Swiss Joint Research Center

 

Contact information: Laboratory Admin page
We would like to thank our sponsors for their support

We focus on interdisciplinary systems problems found in modern, large-scale datacenters.    Our current research projects include specialized operating systems for datacenter applications, hardware support for software-defined networking, and energy-efficient, rack-scale computing.

Key conferences : ASPLOS, ATC, ISCA, NSDI, SIGCOMM, SOCC, SOSP/OSDI.
